Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Automated extraction of vessel data from images to construct new models for vascular networks in plants and animals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Blood is pumped from the heart to the capillaries through a highly branched and interconnected network known as the cardiovascular system, with vessel sizes that range from microns to centimeters and blood flow speeds that differ by a factor of 1000. Similar types of vascular networks are essential for the flow of resources in nearly all multicellular organisms, including plants (xylem networks), insects (tracheal networks), and mammals. Understanding which evolutionary principles and environmental factors drive the structure of vascular networks, and what constrains the flow through them, could help lead to a better understanding of organismic structure and function with implications for systems as diverse as forests, food webs, and even tumors. This research project will supply the data needed to directly test existing models and to develop new, more realistic models. Outputs will be new software for extracting vascular data from images (e.g., Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), Computed Tomography (CT)), a large database for vascular measurements in plants and animals, identification of branching patterns common to specific taxa or tissues, and new theory. Measurements will include vessel radii, lengths, branching ratios, and branching angles. Existing models are contradicted by some preliminary results, including asymmetric branching (two daughter vessels of different sizes and different flow) and deviations from self-similarity (similar branching patterns recurring across scales). New models will be constructed to incorporate these findings and used to predict connections between the geometry of and flow through vascular networks. A key prediction of models will be scaling exponents that describe how the number of capillaries changes with network volume. In an attempt to enable quick translation of branching geometry into predictions for flow rate, techniques will be adapted to classify vascular networks according to a suite of these characteristic scaling exponents.

Closely integrated with these research objectives are three educational goals: 1) teach students how to use image recognition software to extract data from images across biological fields, including museum collections and labs, 2) teach students how to translate empirical results into equations and test specific, mechanistic hypotheses, and 3) motivate data sharing with the public and scientific community via websites for large, comprehensive databases that will accelerate scientific research and community outreach. High school, undergraduate, and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers will all be trained during this research. Notably, summer research experiences for three high school students will be provided for each year of the project. A critical aspect of this training is in teaching students how to combine theory and empirical data and how to disseminate research findings through publications, websites, curricular materials, and talks at professional meetings as well as outreach. The PI has experience educating and training students at all levels and will actively recruit students from under-represented groups to engage in informatics research. Publications, databases, code, and curricular materials will all be made available through websites. Together, this work will provide an example of how computer vision techniques can be used to extract data from biological images around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through work funded by this grant, we have achieved all our major aims. 1. We created Angicart software that prcoesses angiograms--images of blood vessels inside of organisms--and extracts information and data on vessel radius, length, connectivity, branching angles, loopy structures, and more. The original version only applied to branching hierarchical vascular trees, but we have since extended Angicart to apply to loopy networks and any imaging modality (MRI, CT, Clarity, confocal). Moreover, we are now applying these methods to neuron morphology and through other efforts we have obtained a large number of plant network data as well. 2. Based on the software development and data collection in the first aim, we have tested existing vascular theory with data, identified shortcomings, and created new theory to address problems we've found to better align theory with the realities of vascular network. In particular, we've shown that scaling ratios for vessel radii--the ratio of a child vessel to a parent vessel-- has a central tendencay that matches theoretical predictions, while analogous scaling ratios for vessel lengths show no central tendency and do not match theory. In addition, we have measured a substantial amount of asymmetric branching--vessels with different sizes that share the same parent--in both radii and length. Through theoretical work, we have shown that asymmetry in vessel radius has little effect on predictions about blood flow or heart rate or growth so long as the total cross-sectional area of vessels is conserved (known as DaVinci's rule) is maintained, and data show that this tends to be the case. In contrast, the asymmetry in lengths do affect predictions and not follow a conservation law that corresponds to theory. Through a series of papers, we have created new theory to address some of these findings. In our papers we have shown how to model asymmetric branching by perturbing off of symmetic avreage values, how to optimize branching angles between asymmetric child vessels, and how to explore the space of possiblilties to fill the space of the body using asymmetric networks. Results of this new theory show how diverse branching patterns in vascular networks can still lead to canonical relationships such as organismal metabolic rate increaing with body size to the 3/4 exponent. All of this naturally leads to questions about universal classes and equivalenece classes among biological networks. 3. To truly understand vascular networks, we should be able to compare differences among types of biologiical networks--animal versus plant, different organs or tissues, cancer vasulature and stroke recovery vaculature versus healthy vessels--and use them to categorize networks and understand their source and function. A result of this would eventually be categories that correspond to equivalence classes among biological networks. A natural method for categorization is machine-learning. Machine-learning is a powerful tool but often considered a black box. Combining machine-learning with mechanistic theory should only make it more effective and interpretable. Here we take a first step towards building that bridge by using mechanistic theory about vascular networks to choose better feature spaces (data spaces to which machine-learning algorithms are applied). In so doing, we achieve a two-fold, mutually reinforcing benefit: a. We achieve better results for categorizing networks, and b. Results are much more interpretable because the best-performing feature spaces are explicitly and naturally tied to specific mechanisms. With more work in this direction, machine-hearing and mechanistic theory might eventually be combined into a more glass-box approach. For vascular networks specifically, we have shown that feature spaces based on ratios of vessel radii--encapsulating parent-child vessel relations, connectivity, asymmetry, and information about blood flow--are the best at categorizing biological networks. They do significantly better than typical approaches that analyze the raw data of just the vessel radius and length, and we show that for our data this featrue space can be used to distinguish plant from animal networks and plants from non-flowering plants. Because scaling of vessel radii is closely coupled to properties of blood flow, this suggests that strong functional constraints on blood flow, metabolism, and gorwth are instantiated in the architecture of vessel networks in a way that can be captured by these scaling ratios. On the other hand, feature spaces based on scaling ratios of vessel lengths did a poor job of disciminating among networks. Because scaling ratios of vessel lengths, are tightly tied to poperties of how vascular networks fill the space of the body, this suggests that either space-filling geometries are not a major discriminating factor among biological networks or that these scaling ratios do not adequately describe the space-filling and branching properties of real vascular networks (point 2 above). Taking all of this work together, it holds a future promise that could be used for applicaitons as varied as identifying the optinal network strucure for growth for plants in different environments or quantifying growth trajectories and treatment strategies for tumors.
